sectionTitle: D.3: Going to the Temple & Pujä Rituals

tabData.tagHTML: The Jain Temple: A Place of Serenity and Reflection

A Jain temple, known as a Mandir or Deräsar, is a place of worship designed for peace and serenity. It serves as a beautiful and quiet space to reflect upon one's own nature and soul. The goal is to foster introspection and the understanding that God resides within one's own soul, encouraging a path of purification from anger, ego, deceit, and greed.

The temple is often viewed as a replica of the Samavasaran, the divine preaching hall of a living Tirthankar (Jina). The layperson approaches the idol as if approaching a living Jina, using the image as a tangible aid to visualize the sacred being and awaken their own soul.

Idol worship is a prominent feature in the path of devotion.  An idol (murti) in Jainism is not a representation of a Tirthankar's physical body, but rather symbolizes their qualities and the pure state attainable by all souls.  This is why the idols of all Tirthankars look similar.  Looking at the idol's meditative posture reminds us of our own inner pure state and inspires us to achieve it.

tabData.title: Rules of Conduct in a Jain Temple
tabData.description: To maintain the sanctity of the temple, there are special rules one should follow.

items.content: One should wear clean, simple clothes.  Items made from animal products like silk, leather, fur, and pearls are prohibited as they are obtained through violence.  It is recommended to have specific clothes designated just for Pujä.

Before entering, you must take off your shoes. Upon entering, you should say 'Nissihi' three times. This signifies that you are leaving worldly relations and vices like anger, ego, deceit, and greed outside the temple.

Eating, drinking, or chewing anything is not allowed.  One should not run, shout, or socialize inside the temple.  The atmosphere should be kept quiet and conducive to meditation and reflection.  When leaving, one should walk backwards a few steps before turning their back to the main idols.

Before performing Pujä, one should bathe.  If cleaning idols, use a wet cloth gently and a soft brush for thorough cleaning.  If an idol needs to be moved, it should be carried with reverence, supported by both hands from underneath.  Cover your mouth and nose with a multi-layered handkerchief during certain rituals to avoid violence to microscopic beings.

tabData.title: Understanding Tirthankar Idols (Murti)
tabData.description: Tirthankar idols are central to Jain worship. They are typically carved from marble or cast in metal and represent the qualities of a Tirthankar, not their physical body.

items.content:
There are distinct differences between the idols in the two main traditions.
  • Shvetämbar Idols: They are beautifully decorated and depicted with wide-open eyes. The luxurious decoration symbolizes that although Tirthankars were often kings with royal wealth, they renounced it all to find true happiness.
  • Digambar Idols: They are presented in their natural, undecorated form. Their eyes are semi-closed, representing a state of deep meditation.
Both traditions create idols that are either sitting in the Padmäsan (lotus) posture or standing straight, illustrating deep meditation and showering the devotee with compassion.

Since all Tirthankar idols appear similar, each one has a unique emblem or symbol called a Länchhan that distinguishes them. This symbol is carved on the base of the idol. For example, a bull emblem indicates the idol is of Rishabhadev (Ädinäth), the first Tirthankar.

tabData.title: The Ten Rituals of the Temple (Das-Jintrik)
tabData.description: In the Shvetämbar tradition, upon seeing the Tirthankar idol, one should recite 'Namo Jinänam' and then perform ten specific rituals known as Das-Jintrik.

tabData.title: The Eight-Fold Worship (Ashta Prakäri Pujä)
tabData.description: This worship is performed daily using eight different substances.  Each substance is a symbolic representation used to acquire virtues and reflect on spiritual improvement, not to get something in return.

items.content:
Symbolizes: Purity.
Meaning: Offering water symbolizes cleansing the soul of karmic impurities. It reminds us to live a life as pure as water and to cross the ocean of birth and death to attain liberation.

Symbolizes: Tranquility and Knowledge.
Meaning: Offering cool sandalwood paste represents the desire to quell the sufferings of the world and attain tranquility within our soul. This puja is associated with reflecting on Samyag Jnän (Right Knowledge). During this, Nav-anga (9 parts) Pujä is performed by anointing nine parts of the idol while reciting mantras.

Symbolizes: Good Conduct.
Meaning: Offering a flower reminds us that our conduct should be like a flower, offering fragrance and beauty to all without discrimination. To minimize violence, only naturally fallen flowers should be used.

Symbolizes: Life of an ascetic.
Meaning: As incense burns itself to provide fragrance, a monk's life is spent selflessly for the benefit of all. The upward-moving smoke also symbolizes our spiritual journey towards Siddha-kshetra.

Symbolizes: Pure Consciousness / Liberated Soul.
Meaning: The lamp's flame represents the light of knowledge that destroys the darkness of ignorance and false beliefs. It reminds us to follow the five great vows to attain liberation.

Symbolizes: The end of the cycle of birth and death.
Meaning: Unbroken, husked rice (Akshat) cannot be seeded to grow a new plant. This offering represents the goal to live in such a way that this is our final birth.

Symbolizes: Detachment from tasty food.
Meaning: Offering sweets symbolizes the desire to renounce the attachment to food and attain a state where there is no desire for it, a state of a liberated soul.

Symbolizes: Moksh (Liberation).
Meaning: A fruit is the ultimate result of a plant's life. This offering symbolizes Moksh, the ultimate fruit and achievement of our spiritual life, which is attained by living without attachment or expectation of rewards.

tabData.title: An Overview of Digambar Puja
tabData.description: Dev Pujä is one of the six daily essentials for a Jain householder in the Digambar tradition.  It can be done with offerings (Dravya-Pujä) or without (Bhäv-Pujä), and typically takes place in a temple but can also be performed at home.

items.content: A devotee must bathe and wear clean clothes.  Upon entering the temple, one chants 'Nissihi, Nissihi, Nissihi', rings the bells, recites the Namokär Mantra three times, and circumambulates the main altar three times clockwise.  Before the main worship, a Swastik is made with rice grains to signify that the purpose of the puja is to attain liberation.

This is the ritual of bathing the idol, usually with pure water.  The main purpose is to purify our own soul and mind.  On special occasions, Panchämrit Abhishek (using five substances) may be performed, though modern dairy products are discouraged due to violence in the industry.  After bathing, the idol is dried with a clean cloth (Prakshalan).

This is the main puja done with eight substances (Ashta-Dravya).  Only the initial Jal Pujä (Abhishek) involves touching the idol, and is performed only by male members.  The other seven offerings are placed before the idol and can be done by all.  The order and some substances differ from the Shvetämbar tradition. For example, flowers and fruits may be replaced with colored rice and cloves/coconut pieces.

The main worship is followed by Jayamälä (reciting the Tirthankar's virtues), Shänti Path (a peace prayer for all living beings), Visarjan (a concluding prayer asking for forgiveness for any mistakes), and Äarti (waving a lamp). The entire process is integrated with Swädhyäy (study of scriptures).

rows: To overcome the cycle of birth, aging, and death.
To subside worldly sufferings and the passion of anger.
To attain the final state (Akshay Pad); to live so this is the last life.
To abandon passions and the deceit that causes karma accumulation.
To overcome the disease of hunger (kshudhä) and give up the passion of greed.
To destroy the darkness of ignorance and false beliefs (Mithyätva).
To destroy the eight types of Karma (Ashtakarma Vinäshanäya).
To attain the ultimate fruit of all actions: Moksh.
tabData.footnote: The order of pujas differs between traditions. The Shvetämbar order is Jal, Chandan, Pushpa, Dhoop, Deepak, Akshat, Naivedya, Fal.  The Digambar order is Jal, Chandan, Akshat, Pushpa, Naivedya, Deepak, Dhoop, Fal.

tabData.title: Pujas for Special Occasions and Festivals
tabData.description: Besides daily worship, there are many special pujas and more elaborate ceremonies (Pujan) performed on auspicious occasions.

items.content:
• Snätra Pujä: Symbolizes the bathing of a newborn Tirthankar on Mount Meru. It is performed before many special occasions.
  • Panch Kalyänak Pujä: Commemorates the five major life events of a Tirthankar: conception, birth, renunciation, omniscience, and liberation (Moksh).
  • Antaräya Karma Pujä: Performed to remove obstructive (Antaräya) karma.
  • Sattarabhedi Pujä: A puja with seventeen different offerings, often performed on a temple's anniversary.
  • Nav-pad Pujä: Worship of the nine supreme entities (Panch Parameshthi, and the three jewels of right faith, knowledge, conduct, and right austerity).

• Dev Shästra Guru Pujä: Worship of the true God (Vitaräg), Scriptures (Shästra), and Teacher (Guru).
  • Panch Kalyänak Pujä: Adoration of the five auspicious life events of a Tirthankar.
  • Das Lakshan Pujä: Adoration of the ten great virtues of an ascetic, such as forgiveness and humility.
  • Ratna-traya Pujä: Worship of the 'three jewels' - Right Faith, Right Knowledge, and Right Conduct, which form the path to liberation.
  • Solähkaran Pujä: Reflecting on the 16 reasons or deep thoughts that lead to acquiring Tirthankar Näm-karma.

cards.back: A term for a Jain temple, particularly in the Jain tradition.
The divine preaching hall of a Tirthankar. A Jain temple is considered a replica of this.
The unique emblem or symbol at the base of a Tirthankar idol used for identification.
Meaning 'renunciation'. It is said three times when entering a temple to discard worldly thoughts.
Circumambulation. Going around the Jina idols three times, symbolizing the three jewels of Jainism.
The sanctum or area where the Jina idols are placed.
Physical worship performed with material substances or offerings.
Internal or devotional worship, done through reflection, contemplation, and Chaitya-vandan.
Pure, unbroken rice grains used in Pujä, symbolizing the end of the cycle of birth and death.
A type of salutation done by touching five body parts (2 knees, 2 hands, forehead) to the ground. Also known as Khamäsamanu.
The eight-fold worship performed using eight different symbolic substances.
The study of scriptures, which is an essential part of Jain practice and is often integrated with Pujä.
